qas.question: What compression typically operate on square-shaped groups of pixels?
What only sends the differences within those pixels and blocks?
What does high-frequency detail lead to?
What compression typically operate on square-shaped groups of flames?
What only sends the differences within those bitrates?
What do high-frequency explosions lead to?
What sends only the difference within animals?

plausible_answers.text: explosions, flames, flocks of animals, and in some panning shots

qas.question: When does high-frequency detail lead to blocks of pixels?

context: Some <a0_0><b3_0>video<b3_0/><a0_0/> compression schemes typically operate on square-shaped groups of neighboring pixels, often called <a1_0><b4_0>macroblocks<b4_0/><a1_0/>. These pixel groups or blocks of pixels are compared from one frame to the next, and the <b6_0>video compression codec<b6_0/> sends only the differences within those blocks. In areas of video with more motion, the compression must encode more data to keep up with the larger number of pixels that are changing. Commonly during <b7_0>explosions, flames, flocks of animals, and in some panning shots<b7_0/>, the high-frequency detail leads to quality decreases or to increases in the <a2_0><b5_0>variable bitrate<b5_0/><a2_0/>.
